attributes.description:
This visualization displays the distribution of all user activity by 'user.name'.

**Why this visualization works:**
It quickly highlights which users are most active, allowing an analyst to verify that activity is coming from expected user accounts. A sudden appearance of a new user with high activity, or an unexpected concentration of activity from a single user, could be a sign of a compromised account or misconfigured system. This visual aid is perfect for identifying outliers quickly.

**How an analyst can use it:**
Use this pie chart to quickly scan for and identify unexpected or highly active users. Clicking on a slice of the pie chart will apply a filter for that specific user, allowing you to drill down into their activity in the other visualizations to verify if their actions are legitimate. This is a powerful tool for a quick and effective compliance check.

attributes.title: [AU-4, CCI-001848] Audit Activity by User

attributes.description:
This visualization displays the maximum anomaly score over time for the job monitoring auditable user activities. 

**Why this visualization works:** This visualization is essential because it uses machine learning to establish a baseline of normal user activity and flags deviations from that norm. It can detect subtle, suspicious behaviors that might be missed by static rules. For instance, a user who normally only logs in during business hours suddenly accessing systems at 3 AM from an unusual location would generate a high anomaly score, indicating a potential compromise or insider threat. 

**How an analyst can use it:** Look for spikes in the anomaly score. A high score is a critical signal that warrants immediate investigation. You can use the time selector to isolate these periods and apply filters for 'influencers.user.name' or 'influencers.host.name' to pinpoint the specific user and system involved. This helps you determine if the activity was legitimate or if further action is required.
attributes.title: [AU-4, CCI-001848] ML - User Activity Anomaly Score Trend (converted)

attributes.description: This section provides visualizations to help you assess compliance with CCI-001848, focusing on ensuring that the actions of individual users can be uniquely traced back to them. This visualization now displays the health status of user action traceability for CCI-001848 based on the anomaly scores from the associated ML job.
attributes.title: [AU-4, CCI-001848] Audit Logging - User Action Traceability ML

attributes.description:
This table provides a detailed breakdown of individual events related to user activities. 

**Why this visualization works:**
It offers granular detail on each event, including the user, host, and the specific action attempted. This level of detail is crucial for in-depth investigation and pinpointing exactly what a user did and when, directly supporting the core requirement of this CCI.

**How an analyst can use it:**
Sort by '@timestamp' to see the most recent events, or by 'user.name' to identify all actions taken by a specific user. Examine 'host.name' to see which component the action took place on. This table is essential for verifying that every user action is being logged and can be traced back to an individual, fulfilling the compliance requirement.

attributes.title: [AU-4, CCI-001848] Detailed User Activity Events

attributes.description:
This visualization displays a time-series trend of auditable user activities over time. 

**Why this visualization works:**
It provides a quick visual of spikes or consistent activity patterns, allowing analysts to correlate user actions with specific time periods. This helps in understanding the normal rhythm of a system and spotting unusual behavior. It confirms that auditable events are being consistently logged.

**How an analyst can use it:**
Look for sudden increases or decreases in activity that are not aligned with normal business hours or expected behavior. Hover over data points to see the event count at a specific time. Use the time range selector to focus on periods of interest and see if the activity is related to an expected user or process. This helps in verifying that all user actions are being captured and that the auditing system is operational.
